Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Co-Evolution of Upstream Human Behavior and Downstream Ecosystem Services in a Changing Climate

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-point source nutrient and sediment runoff from upstream agricultural production is impairing coastal ecosystem services across the globe, including the Great Lakes, Chesapeake Bay, the northern Gulf of Mexico, and other regions of economic, recreational, and cultural importance. This degradation is projected to worsen with continued climate change, as more intense rains transport more nutrients and sediments downstream with impacts that include reduced water clarity, increases in harmful algal blooms, and a loss of high-valued fish stocks. To address these problems, many agricultural management practices have been identified that can reduce sediment and nutrient runoff. Effective design of policies to encourage adoption of effective agricultural management practices is limited by an important knowledge gap concerning human behavioral responses to ecosystem conditions, however. This interdisciplinary research project will use the Maumee River watershed and western Lake Erie as a model ecosystem to quantify the co-evolution between upstream human behavior and downstream ecosystem services. The investigators will model how public attitudes co-evolve with downstream ecosystem conditions and shape support for policies that impact agricultural management practices, and in turn, how farmers respond to these policies and public attitudes. They also will integrate biophysical models of the study region with behavioral models of public policy and farmer decision making to predict the co-evolution among public policies, farmer behavior, and downstream ecosystems under possible future scenarios. This modeling of the two-way coupling between upstream human behavior and downstream ecosystem services will address the question of whether changes in upstream public attitudes, policies, and farmer behavior will offset anticipated negative impacts of climate change on downstream ecosystem services.

This project will develop a coupled human-natural system model that focuses on the dynamic feedback between upstream human behavioral responses and downstream ecosystem change. It will provide an assessment of how farmer behavioral responses mediate the interactions between specific policies and changing ecological conditions, and it will enhance understanding regarding the capacity of state and local policy makers to influence farmer behavior and downstream ecosystem conditions in ways that may counteract the expected negative impacts of climate change. While substantial research has focused on the one-way impacts of upstream nutrient inputs and fluxes on watershed functioning and downstream ecosystem services, key reverse linkages that shape public, policy, and farmer responses to ecological changes have received much less attention. The integrated model will provide the theoretical foundation for assessing the dynamic linkages between human attitudes and behaviors and downstream ecological conditions and will improve predictions of the dynamic effect of changing behavioral activities and climate on the availability and quality of downstream ecosystem services. This predictive knowledge is relevant to societal concerns because it will improve the ability of decision makers in coastal watersheds to manage adaptively to address negative impacts of climate change. The project also will provide education, training, and mentoring for undergraduate and graduate students and post-doctoral researchers. The investigators will work directly with Grade 6-12 teachers within rural school districts in the Maumee watershed to develop watershed science curriculum, and they will disseminate results more broadly by working with the Ohio Sea Grant College Program to develop and distribute materials targeted at decision makers and the general public. This project is supported by the NSF Dynamics of Coupled Natural and Human Systems (CNH) Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Methods Summary:

To understand how farmers and landowners make decisions about the adoption of management practices we conducted focus groups and surveys of residents in Lake Erie’s largest watershed, the Maumee River. These instruments analyzed how socio-psychological, socio-demographic, and field based spatial characteristics impact farmers' adoption of management practices.

To evaluate the physical impacts of different management practices and adoption levels, we formed a regional watershed modeling collaborative of 6 institutions (Ohio State University, University of Michigan, Heidelberg University, Limnotech, USGS, University of Toledo), each with a calibrated model of the Maumee watershed. We then formed and worked with Stakeholder Advisory Groups to identify and evaluate management strategies to reduce the discharge of phosphorus from the Maumee. With these models we assessed load reduction strategies for the agriculturally dominated Maumee River watershed, the largest P source contributing to toxic algal blooms in Lake Erie. The goal was to evaluate what types of practices and adoption levels were capable of reaching the target of a 40% reduction of both total and dissolved phosphorus entering Lake Erie from the Maumee. 

We also used an integrated biophysical modeling approach to explore how harmful algal bloom severity will change in temperate ecosystems dominated by agriculture, using Lake Erie (USA-Canada) as our focal ecosystem. Our approach used an ensemble of global climate model predictions to drive a Maumee watershed model. Outputs from the watershed model informed a model of Lake Erie algal blooms that determine impacts on bloom severity. Linking fisheries models, determined the impact of future changes in Maumee River flow and water quality upon Lake Erie game fish.

Results Summary:

Surveys of farmers determined that policies and outreach efforts aimed at increasing farmers' perceived efficacy of practices could lead to higher adoption levels. When farmers think that a practice is effective, they are more likely to implement it.

By forming the regional watershed modeling collaborative, we were the first to evaluate policy-relevant land management scenarios with multiple models. This approach identified management pathways with the potential to reach the 40% reduction of phosphorus reaching western Lake Erie. But, it should be emphasized that increased adoption levels of successful practices are required to reach this goal.

Using an integrated biophysical modeling approach focused on the Lake Erie ecosystem, we were the first test and confirm the hypothesis that continued climate change will increase the frequency of severe harmful cyanobacteria blooms in agriculturally dominated temperate lake ecosystems. Increased precipitation-driven river discharge that promotes nutrient delivery from the watershed and increased air temperature that promotes cyanobacteria growth underlie our modeling projections. Our study points to land-use management as a means to potentially counteract anticipated climate-change effects in temperate ecosystems dominated by agriculture and offers a readily adoptable modeling approach to forecast climate change impacts on algal blooms in other ecosystems.

Results for game fish are important because they suggest that anticipated climate change will drive changes in fish community composition that will negatively affect Lake Erie’s fisheries. Ultimately, our work supports the notion that climate change could be detrimental to other native cold- and cool-water species and populations in north-temperate lakes, and that climate change may exacerbate the expansion of invasive species that prefer warm thermal regimes. Also, our findings indicate that tradeoffs can be expected to occur with the anticipated implementation of agricultural conservation practices and climate change. For example, conditions that promote strong Lake Erie fisheries (i.e., cold temperatures, moderate to higher nutrient loading) also led to stream fish communities in poor health. These findings point to the need for regulatory and management agencies across disciplines to work together to identify how important ecosystem attributes might respond to climate change and land-use management, perhaps using an integrative ecosystem assessment approach.

Unique Coupled Human and Natural Systems Results:

By coupling human behavioral and watershed modeling results, we are now attempting to identify more feasible management scenarios that have potential to meet phosphorus reduction targets. An initial management scenario that was capable or reaching the 40% phosphorus reduction target required 78% of farmed acres to adopt buffer strips, 58% to adopt cover crops, and 50% subsurface placement of phosphorus fertilizer. However, we know that 78% adoption level of buffer strips is unlikely because this practice takes land out of production. Subsequent surveys revealed likely adoption levels for cover crops of 60% and subsurface application of 68%. Now, to identify more realistic scenarios capable of meeting the reduction target, we are analyzing scenarios with these levels of cover crops and subsurface placement, and lower, but more realistic levels of buffer strips adoption. In this way we are coupling knowledge about human behavior and physical systems to address important management and policy needs.
